question: It is true that deadlock occurs when two or more processes are waiting for resources but cannot proceed because they are waiting on each other.
It is false that deadlock is a situation where all processes proceed without waiting for resources.
It is true that a system is in a deadlock when the conditions of mutual exclusion, hold and wait, no preemption, and circular wait are all satisfied simultaneously.
It is false that deadlock cannot occur if any one of the necessary conditions is prevented.
It is true that mutual exclusion means a resource can only be used by one process at a time.
It is false that the hold and wait condition means that a process waits for all resources before starting its execution.
It is true that circular wait happens when a chain of processes exist, where each process is waiting for a resource held by the next process in the chain.
It is false that deadlock can be prevented by allowing processes to preempt resources without any restrictions.
It is true that to prevent deadlock, we can prevent circular wait by assigning resources in a fixed sequence.
It is false that deadlock prevention ensures that resources cannot be preempted once a process has started using them.
